As a relief from the usual run
of assembly speakers, yesterday's
audience was heartily amused by
Mr. John Mulholland, scholarly
magician and sleight of hand trickster.
When the entertainment had been
concluded, one bird and cage had
disappeared, eight steel rings had
been mysteriously linked and unlinked, knotted handkerchiefs had
lost their knots and travelled
through space, thimbles had multiplied and vanished, and card tricks
had been witnessed, the like of
which have never been seen before,
even a telephone book was employed in the proceedings.
Conjurer Philosophizes

"A magician moves slowly, nor is
there any relationship between
what he says and does," said the
Conjurer as he proceeded to squeeze
a pile of thimbles into nothingness.
"A magician tells a long story
and proves it by a little trick."

Herewith, there knotted handkerchiefs in the hands of one member
of the audience lost their knots, and
there transferred them through
space into the hands of another gentleman who had just a moment before been holding three unknotted
handkerchiefs in his hands.
Engages In Repartee

Between tricks Mr. Mulholland
engaged in repartee with the scoffing sceptics seated in the front row.
The eminent business manager of
the NEWS-LETTER insisted that
there was "something crooked"
about the mysterious connections
between eight separate still rings.
His attempts to verify his suspicions met with little success, for the
recromancer, upholding the adage
that his profession always dictates
its own terms, proceeded to talk him
out of his incredulity, taking care,
however, not to allow him to get a
too close view of the ring whose
"honesty" was questioned.

N PLANNING the 1931 June Week, the committee has seen fit to
place faith in the underclassmen's support. Exactly three tickets
were sold to underclassmen at last year's June Week. It seems that for
some unknown reason, ugderclassmen have the opinion that the affair
is only for seniors. In the past, as the programs have not been very
elaborate, the seniors have been able to carry the burden. This year,
the committee wishes to alter this situation. A very extensive program
is being planned, including Guy Lombardo's orchestra at the June
Ball. In spite of this fact the ticket price to undergraduates has been
reduced.
When the committee decided to elaborate on the program, tw 1
methods of proceedure to make up the necessary revenue were open.
Either the affair could be extensively advertised and made open to the
public, or June Week would have to have the whole-hearted support
of the entire student body. It would be impossible for the senior class
to conduct such a program without some financial assistance. Now that
the committee has decided to adopt the latter course, we hope that the
underclassmen will justify this procedure by attending the June Week
affairs. The entire program has not been definitely planned as yet, but
it may be seen from the article appearing in today's NEWS-LETTER
that the price offered to the men in the first three years is very reasonable.
The June Week committee has by this action shown that it believes
that the undergraduate school at Hopkins is not dying out, but on th.
contrary building up every year. We hope that they are not wrong
in this assumption.

"Within the past year and a half there has been considerable change
in the attitude of undergraduates of American colleges and universities towards the maintenance of certain so-called "college traditions."
In most instances this movement has resulted in a general housecleaning and throwing overboard of undesirable practices and regulations.
Lehigh has come in for its share of the incoming freshmen by abolishing rushes and class banquet fueds. One of the customers was the
"hello" habit which remained because of its real value.
Intended primarily as a means for permitting men to become mor?
easily acquainted, the "hello" habit has grown into a genuine tradition.
It has been the greeting between Lehigh men for the past 38 years. Its
perpetuation was each year entrusted to the freshman class who when
they became upperclassmen realized the good of the "hello" habit and
insured its continuance.
At present the "hello" habit seems to be losing its grip on the Lehigh undergraduate and the cause does not lie with the freshman class
alone. Upperclassmen have been sluggish in their observance also. Men
who do adhere to it, sometimes regard it as a duty which should be
propagated only because of its background.
The "hello" habit need not be defended. Its place in Lehigh has
been definitely established. What is lacking is a realization of these
facts by the undergraduate. Swing into the spirit of a real "hello." It's
a Lehigh custom.
Don't forget that this is also a Hopkins custom.

that the undergraduate school at Hopkins is not dying out, but on th.
contrary building up every year. We hope that they are not wrong
